column1: Tampa (US: ) is a major city in
column2: and the county seat of
column3: Hillsborough County
column4: Florida
column5: United States. It is on the west coast of Florida on Tampa Bay
column6: near the Gulf of Mexico. Tampa is the largest city in the Tampa Bay Area. With an estimated population of 399

column2: Tampa is part of the metropolitan area most commonly referred to as the "Tampa Bay Area". For U.S. Census purposes

column1: When the pioneer community living near the US Army outpost of Fort Brooke was incorporated in 1849
column2: it was called "Tampa Town"
column3: and the name was shortened to simply "Tampa" in 1855.

column1: The earliest instance of the name "Tampa"
column2: in the form "Tanpa"
column3: appears in the memoirs of Hernando de Escalante Fontaneda
column4: who spent 17 years as a captive of the Calusa and traveled through much of peninsular Florida. He described Tanpa as an important Calusa town to the north of the Calusa domain
column5: possibly under another chief. Archaeologist Jerald Milanich places the town of Tanpa at the mouth of Charlotte Harbor. The entrances to Tampa Bay and Charlotte Harbor are obscured by barrier islands
column6: and their locations
column7: and the names applied to them
column8: were a source of confusion to explorers
column9: surveyors and map-makers from the 16th century though the 18th century. Bahía Tampa and Bahía de Espíritu Santo were each used
column11: for the modern Tampa Bay and Charlotte Harbor. Tampa Bay was labeled Bahía de Espíritu Santo (Bay of the Holy Spirit) in the earliest Spanish maps of Florida
column12: but became known as Bahía Tampa (Tampa Bay) as early as 1695. "B. Tampa"
column14: appeared on a British map of 1705
column15: with "Carlos Bay" for Charlotte Harbor to the south
column16: while a 1748 British map had "B. del Spirito Santo" for Tampa Bay
column19: "Carlos Bay" to the south. A Spanish map of 1757 renamed Tampa Bay as "San Fernando". As late as 1774
column20: Bernard Romans called Tampa Bay "Bay of Espiritu Santo"
column21: with "Tampa Bay" restricted to the Northwest arm (what is now Old Tampa Bay)
column22: and the northeast arm named "Hillsborough Bay". The name may have come from the Calusa language
column24: the Timucua language. Some scholars have compared "Tampa" to "itimpi"
column25: which means "close to or nearby" in the Creek language
column26: but its meaning is not known.People from Tampa are generally known as "Tampans" or "Tampanians". Local authorities consulted by Michael Kruse of the Tampa Bay Times suggest that "Tampan" was historically more common
column27: while "Tampanian" became popular when the former term came to be seen as a potential insult. A mix of Cuban
column29: and Spanish immigrants began arriving in the late 1800s to found and work in the new communities of Ybor City and West Tampa. By about 1900
column30: these newcomers came to be known as "Tampeños" (or "Tampeñas" for females)
column31: a term that is still sometimes used to refer to their descendants living in the area
column33: to all residents of Tampa regardless of their ethnic background.

column1: The shores of Tampa Bay have been inhabited for thousands of years. A variant of the Weeden Island culture developed in the area by about 2000 years ago
column2: with archeological evidence suggesting that these residents relied on the sea for most of their resources
column3: as a vast majority of inhabited sites have been found on or near the shoreline and there is little evidence of farming.

column1: At the time of European contact in the early 16th century
column2: the Safety Harbor culture dominated the area
column3: with indigenous peoples organized into three or four chiefdoms around the shores of the bay. Early Spanish explorers to visit the area interacted extensively (and violently) with the Tocobaga
column4: whose principal town was at the northern end of Old Tampa Bay near today's Safety Harbor in Pinellas County. While there is a substantial historical record of the Tocobaga (and the Calusa
column5: who lived far to the south)
column6: there is less surviving documentation describing the Pohoy chiefdom
column7: which controlled the area near the mouth of the Hillsborough River near today's downtown Tampa. However
column8: brief mentions by explorers along with surviving artifacts suggest that the Pohoy and other groups that once lived on Tampa Bay had very similar cultures and lifestyles as the better-documented Tocobaga.Expeditions led by Pánfilo de Narváez and Hernando de Soto landed near Tampa
column9: but neither conquistador stayed long. There is no natural gold or silver in Florida
column10: and the native inhabitants repulsed Spanish attempts to establish a permanent settlement or convert them to Catholicism. The fighting resulted in a few deaths
column11: but the many more deaths were caused by infectious diseases brought from Europe
column12: which devastated the population of Native Americans across Florida and the entire Western Hemisphere. The indigenous cultures of the Tampa Bay area had collapsed by around 1600
column13: leaving the west coast of Spanish Florida largely depopulated and ignored for more than 200 years.In the mid-18th century
column14: events in the American colonies and the early United States drove the Seminole people into northern Florida
column15: but they did not move into central Florida until after the United States gained control of Florida in 1821. Before the American period
column16: the Tampa Bay area had a handful of residents: Cuban and Native American fishermen who established small seasonal camps called "ranchos" on the shores of Tampa Bay. The largest was at the mouth of Spanishtown Creek in today's Hyde Park neighborhood along Bayshore Boulevard.

column1: After purchasing Florida from Spain in 1821
column2: the United States built forts and trading posts in the new territory. Fort Brooke was established in January 1824 at the mouth of the Hillsborough River on Tampa Bay
column3: in Downtown Tampa.Tampa was initially an isolated frontier outpost. The sparse civilian population practically abandoned the area during the Second Seminole War from 1835 to 1842
column4: after which the Seminoles were forced out and many settlers returned.

column1: Florida became the 27th state on March 3
column2: 1845. On January 18
column4: Tampa was officially incorporated as the "Village of Tampa". It was home to 185 civilians
column5: or 974 total residents including military personnel
column6: in 1850. Tampa was reincorporated as a town on December 15

column2: Florida seceded along with most of the southern states to form the Confederate States of America
column3: and Fort Brooke was manned by Confederate troops. Martial law was declared in Tampa in January 1862
column4: and Tampa's city government ceased to operate for the duration of the war.In 1861
column5: the Union Navy set up a blockade around many southern ports to cut off the Confederacy. Several US Navy ships were stationed near the mouth of Tampa Bay
column6: but small blockade running ships were often able to slip by the blockade to deliver cattle to Spanish Cuba
column7: earning gold for the Confederate cause. On June 30
column9: the gunboat USS Sagamore sailed into Tampa Bay and opened fire on Fort Brooke
column10: which returned fire. The Sagamore withdrew after a few hours
column11: and the Battle of Tampa caused little damage. During the Battle of Fort Brooke on October 16 and the Battle of Ballast Point on October 18
column13: Union forces inflicted serious damage to the city's economy when
column14: under the cover of another bombardment of the fort
column15: troops landed and destroyed two blockade running ships that had been hidden upstream along the Hillsborough River. In May 1864
column16: Union troops landed again and took Fort Brooke largely unopposed. They destroyed much of the fort's facilities and confiscated the remaining military supplies other than the canons
column17: which they tossed into the Hillsborough River
column18: then left the "desolate" town after two days.The Civil War ended in April 1865 with a Confederate defeat. In May 1865
column19: federal troops arrived in Tampa to occupy the fort and the town as part of Reconstruction. They remained until August 1869.

column2: Tampa was a poor
column3: isolated fishing village with about 1000 residents and little industry. Yellow fever
column4: borne by mosquitoes from nearby swamps
column5: broke out several times during the 1860s and 1870s
column6: causing more residents to leave. In 1869
column7: residents voted to abolish the city of Tampa government. The population of "Tampa Town" was about 800 by 1870 and dropped to about 700 by 1880. Fort Brooke was decommissioned in 1883
column8: further impacting the local economy in the short run but opening up the waterfront for development. Except for two cannons displayed on the University of Tampa campus
column9: all traces of the fort are gone.

column2: Tampa's fortunes took several sudden turns for the better. First
column3: phosphate was discovered in the Bone Valley region southeast of Tampa in 1883. The mineral
column4: vital for the production of fertilizers and other products
column5: was soon being shipped from the Port of Tampa in great volume. Tampa is still a major phosphate exporter.

column2: the arrival of Plant's railroad
column3: and the founding of Ybor City and West Tampa—all in the mid-1880s—were crucial to Tampa's development. The once-struggling village of Tampa became a bustling boomtown almost overnight and had grown into one of the largest cities in Florida by 1900.

column1: Henry B. Plant's narrow-gauge South Florida Railroad reached Tampa and its port in late 1883
column2: finally connecting the small town to the nation's railroad system after years of efforts by local leaders. Previously
column3: Tampa's overland transportation links had consisted of sandy roads stretching across the Florida countryside. Plant's railroad made it much easier to get goods in and out of the Tampa Bay area. Phosphate and commercial fishing exports could be sent north by rail
column4: and many new products were brought into the Tampa market
column5: along with the first tourists.

column1: The new railroad link enabled another important industry to come to Tampa. In 1885
column2: the Tampa Board of Trade enticed Vicente Martinez Ybor to move his cigar manufacturing operations to Tampa from Key West. Proximity to Cuba made importation of "clear Havana tobacco" easy by sea
column3: and Plant's railroad made shipment of finished cigars to the rest of the US market easy by land.Since Tampa was still a small town at the time (population less than 5
column5: Ybor built hundreds of small houses around his factory to accommodate the immediate influx of mainly Cuban and Spanish cigar workers. Ybor City's factories rolled their first cigars in 1886
column6: and many different cigar manufacturers moved their operations to town in ensuing years. Many Italian and a few eastern European Jewish immigrants arrived starting in the late 1880s
column7: opening businesses and shops that catered to cigar workers. By 1900
column8: over 10
column9: 000 immigrants had moved to the neighborhood. Several thousand more Cuban immigrants built West Tampa
column10: another cigar-centric suburb founded a few years later by Hugh MacFarlane. Between them
column11: two "Latin" communities combined to exponentially expand Tampa's population
column14: as Tampa became the "Cigar Capital of the World".

column1: During the first few decades of the 20th century
column2: the cigar-making industry was the backbone of Tampa's economy. The factories in Ybor City and West Tampa made an enormous number of cigars—in the peak year of 1929
column3: over 500 million cigars were hand rolled in the city.In 1904
column4: a civic association of local businessmen dubbed themselves Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla (named after local mythical pirate José Gaspar)
column5: and staged an "invasion" of the city followed by a parade. With a few exceptions
column6: the Gasparilla Pirate Festival has been held every year since.

column2: illegal bolita lotteries were very popular among the Tampa working classes
column3: especially in Ybor City. In the early 1920s
column4: this small-time operation was taken over by Charlie Wall
column5: the rebellious son of a prominent Tampa family
column6: and went big-time. Bolita was able to openly thrive only because of kick-backs and bribes to key local politicians and law enforcement officials
column7: and many were on the take.Profits from the bolita lotteries and Prohibition-era bootlegging led to the development of several organized crime factions in the city. Charlie Wall was the first major boss
column8: but various power struggles culminated in consolidation of control by Sicilian mafioso Santo Trafficante Sr. and his faction in the 1950s. After his death in 1954 from cancer
column9: control passed to his son
column11: who established alliances with families in New York City and extended his power throughout Florida and into Batista-era Cuba.The era of rampant and open corruption ended in the 1950s
column12: when Estes Kefauver's traveling organized crime hearings came to town and were followed by the sensational misconduct trials of several local officials. Although many of the worst offenders in government and the mob were not charged
column13: the trials helped to end the sense of lawlessness which had prevailed in Tampa for decades.

column1: Tampa grew considerably as a result of World War II. Prior to the United States' involvement in the conflict
column2: construction began on MacDill Field
column3: which served as a main base for Army Air Corps and later Army Air Forces operations just before and during World War II
column4: with multiple auxiliary airfields around the Tampa Bay area and surrounding counties. At the end of the war
column5: MacDill remained as an active military installation
column6: while the auxiliary fields reverted to civilian control. Two of these auxiliary fields would later become the present-day Tampa International Airport and St. Pete–Clearwater International Airport. With the establishment of an independent U.S. Air Force in 1947
column7: MacDill Field became MacDill Air Force Base.

column2: Tampa saw record-setting population growth that has not been seen since. This growth spurred expansion of the city's highways and bridges
column3: bringing thousands into the city and creating opportunities for Tampa business owners
column4: who welcomed the influx of tourists and new residents. It was during this time period in the city's history that two of the most popular tourist attractions in the area were developed – Busch Gardens and Lowry Park. Many of the well-known institutions that play an important role in the economic development of the city were established during this time period.The University of South Florida was established in North Tampa in 1956 and opened for students in September 1960. The school spurred the construction of several residential and commercial developments in the previously agriculture-dominated area around the new campus. Overall

column6: schools

column8: the U.S. Census Bureau reported city's population as 80.0% white and 19.7% black.Four attempts have been made to consolidate the municipal government of the city of Tampa with the county government of Hillsborough County (1967

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: The Tampa Bay area has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) zone
column2: although due to its location on the Florida peninsula on Tampa Bay and the Gulf of Mexico
column3: it shows some characteristics of a tropical climate. Tampa's climate generally features hot and humid summers with frequent thunderstorms and dry and mild winters. Average highs range from 70 to 90 °F (21 to 32 °C) year round
column4: and lows 52 to 76 °F (11 to 24 °C). The city of Tampa is split between two USDA climate zones. According to the 2012 USDA Plant Hardiness Zone Map
column5: Tampa is listed as USDA zone 9b north of Kennedy Boulevard away from the bay and 10a near the shorelines and in the interbay peninsula south of Kennedy Boulevard. Zone 10a is about the northern limit of where coconut palms and royal palms can be grown
column6: although some specimens do grow in northern Tampa. Recently
column7: certain palm tree species in the area
column8: along with the rest of the state
column9: have been and continue to be severely affected by a plant disease called Texas phoenix palm decline
column10: which has caused a considerable amount of damage to various local palm tree landscapes and threatens the native palm tree species in the region.

column1: Though threatened by tropical systems almost every hurricane season (which runs from June 1 to November 30)
column2: Tampa seldom feels major effects from tropical storms or hurricanes. No hurricane has made landfall in the immediate Tampa Bay area since the 1921 Tampa Bay hurricane made landfall near Tarpon Springs and caused extensive damage throughout the region.Three major hurricanes have seriously threatened Tampa in the ensuing decades. Hurricane Donna (1960)
column3: Hurricane Charley (2004)
column4: and Hurricane Irma (2017) were each forecast to make landfall in Tampa Bay from the southwest
column5: a worst-case track that would result in maximum storm surges throughout the region. However
column6: all three storms turned to the east and made landfall in southwest Florida instead. Irma had the greatest effect on Tampa. It made landfall near Marco Island on September 10
column7: 2017 and moved due north
column8: passing through eastern Hillsborough County as a Category 1 storm. Irma caused substantial damage to the area
column9: particularly to the electrical grid.Because of tremendous population growth and coastal development since the last hurricane strike combined with rising sea levels due to climate change
column10: Tampa and the entire Tampa Bay area is considered one of the most vulnerable regions in the world to a direct hit from a major storm.

column1: Summertime weather patterns predominate from around mid-May through mid-October
column2: which roughly coincides with the rainy season. Daily temperatures are very consistent during this period
column3: with daytime highs very often measuring near 90 °F (32 °C) and lows in the mid- to upper 70s °F (23–25 °C)
column4: almost always accompanied by high humidity. Mainly due to the proximity of large bodies of water
column5: the official high temperature has never hit 100 °F (37.8 °C) – the all-time record high temperature is 99 °F (37 °C)
column6: recorded on June 5
column7: 1985 and June 26
column8: 2020. Afternoon thunderstorms
column9: usually generated by the interaction of the Gulf and Atlantic sea breezes
column10: are such a regular occurrence during the summer that the Tampa Bay area and nearby inland areas of Central Florida are recognized as the "Lightning Capital of North America". Afternoon thundershowers occasionally intensify into a severe thunderstorm
column11: bringing heavy downpours

column1: Average temperatures gradually fall beginning in September
column2: and average daily rainfall amounts also decrease as autumn progresses; November is usually Tampa's driest month. However
column3: rain totals in the fall can be augmented by passing tropical systems
column4: which can dump several inches of rain.

column1: Winter in the area is generally dry and mild. Average high temperatures range from the high-60s to low-70s °F (21–24 °C) during the day to the low to mid- 50s °F (10–13 °C) at night. Occasional cold fronts push through the area during the season
column2: usually bringing a brief period of rain followed by daytime highs in the 50s °F (10–13 °C) and nighttime lows near 40s (5 C) for a day or two. Tampa averages two days of frost per year
column3: although a winter or two may pass without any frost.

column1: Since the Tampa area is home to a diverse range of freeze-sensitive agriculture and aquaculture
column2: hard freezes
column3: although quite rare
column4: are a major concern. Hard freezes (defined as a temperature of 28 °F (−2.2 °C) or below for several hours) occur rarely in the Tampa area; every five to twenty years depending on the exact location. The last widespread freeze occurred on the morning of January 18
column6: when the official temperature at Tampa International Airport dropped to 29 °F (−2 °C). The lowest temperature ever recorded in Tampa was 18 °F (−8 °C) on December 13
column7: 1962. The only snowfall officially recorded in Tampa occurred on January 19
column9: with local accumulations ranging between a trace and 0.2 inches (0.5 cm).

column1: Tampa sees a slow increase in average temperatures beginning in mid-February
column2: and spring brings mostly warm and sunny weather to the area. While temperatures in late spring approach summertime values
column3: the rainy season does not usually begin until June
column4: leading to the threat of brush fires from approximately late March until May. Occasionally
column5: a late-season cold front pushes through the area
column6: potentially bringing a brief round of severe weather followed by a few days of unseasonably cool temperatures.

column5: which caused numerous projects to be delayed or revamped
column6: and some of the 20 projects TDP lists have not broken ground and are being refinanced. Nonetheless several developments were completed
column7: making downtown into a 24-hour neighborhood instead of a 9 to 5 business district. As of 2010
column8: Tampa residents faced a decline in rent of 2%. Nationally rent had decreased 4%. The Tampa Business Journal found Tampa to be the number two city for real estate investment in 2014.Tampa's port is now the seventh largest in the nation and Florida's largest tonnage port
column9: handling nearly half of all seaborne commerce that passes through the state. Tampa ranks second in the state behind Miami in terms of cruise ship travel. Besides smaller regional cruise ships such as Yacht Starship and SunCruz Casino
column10: Tampa also serves as a port of call for three cruise lines: Holland America's MS Ryndam
column11: Royal Caribbean's Grandeur of the Seas and Radiance of the Seas
column12: and Carnival's Inspiration and Legend.The main server farm for Wikipedia and other Wikimedia Foundation projects is in Tampa.

column8: Florida Championship Wrestling

Plant Museum; and Ybor City Museum State Park. Permanently docked in downtown's Channel District is the SS American Victory
column3: a former World War II Victory ship which is now used as a museum ship. Florida Museum of Photographic Arts Features local and international photography exhibitions.

column1: The Children's Museum of Tampa opened in 1986. It was created in response to the need for informal cultural and learning environment for the need of young children. It has since grown into a Larger location in Downtown Tampa next to the Tampa Museum of Art and Curtis Hixon Park. This location opened in September 2010 and was renamed Glazer Children's Museum in honor of the Glazer Family Foundation that donated $5 million to the construction of the new building.
Tampa has a diverse culinary scene from small cafes and bakeries to bistros and farm-to-table restaurants. The food of Tampa has a history of Cuban

column3: Floribbean and Italian cuisines. There are also many Colombian
column4: Puerto Rican
column5: Vietnamese and barbecue restaurants. Seafood is very popular in Tampa

column4: the invasion flotilla led by the pirate ship
column5: Jose Gasparilla
column6: and subsequent parade draw over 400
column7: 000 attendees
column8: contributing tens of millions of dollars to the city's economy. Beyond the initial invasion

column11: the more adult-oriented Sant'Yago Knight Parade
column14: and the Gasparilla International Film Festival

column25: and African-Cuban immigrant heritage. The India International Film Festival (IIFF) of Tampa Bay also takes place in February. In April the MacDill Air Fest entertains as one of the largest military air shows in the U.S. Guavaween
column26: a nighttime street celebration infuses Halloween with the Latin flavor of Ybor City. Downtown Tampa hosts the largest anime convention in Florida

column29: an annual street party in the LGBT-friendly GaYbor district. The Tampa International Gay and Lesbian Film Festival
column31: is the city's largest film festival event
column32: and one of the largest independent gay film festivals in the country.Tampa hosted the 2012 Republican National Convention and the 15th International Indian Film Academy Awards in April 2014.Since 2015

column1: Tampa is represented by teams in three major professional sports leagues: the National Football League
column2: the National Hockey League
column3: and Major League Baseball. The NFL's Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the NHL's Tampa Bay Lightning call Tampa home
column4: while the Tampa Bay Rays of the MLB play across the bay in St. Petersburg. As indicated by their names
column5: these teams
column6: plus several other sports teams
column7: represent the entire Tampa metropolitan area.

column1: The Tampa Bay area has long been a site for Major League Baseball spring training facilities and minor league baseball teams. The New York Yankees conduct spring training in Tampa
column2: and the Tampa Tarpons play there in the summer. On the collegiate level
column3: the University of South Florida Bulls comepete in 17 sports in NCAA Division I and the University of Tampa Spartans compete in 20 sports in NCAA Division II.

column1: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers began in 1976 as an expansion team of the NFL. They struggled at first
column2: losing their first 26 games in a row to set a league record for futility. After a brief taste of success in the late 1970s
column3: the Bucs again returned to their losing ways
column4: and at one point lost at least 10 games for 12 seasons in a row. The hiring of Tony Dungy in 1996 started an improving trend that eventually led to the team's victory in Super Bowl XXXVII in 2003 under coach Jon Gruden.

column1: Tampa has hosted four Super Bowls: Super Bowl XVIII (1984)
column2: Super Bowl XXV (1991)
column3: Super Bowl XXXV (2001)
column4: and Super Bowl XLIII (2009). The first two events were held at Tampa Stadium
column5: and the other two at Raymond James Stadium. Tampa will be the host for Super Bowl LV in 2021.

column1: Originally the Pittsburgh Gladiators and a charter member of the Arena Football League (AFL)
column2: the Tampa Bay Storm relocated from Pittsburgh in 1991 and won ArenaBowl V that year. They later won 4 more ArenaBowls (VII
column3: IX
column4: X
column5: and XVII
column6: and also appeared in ArenaBowl I
column7: III
column8: XII
column9: XXIII and XXX)
column10: and their five championships is the most in league history. The AFL suffered through several years of decreasing revenue in the 2010s
column11: leading to fewer active franchises. There were only five teams during the 2017 season
column12: after which the Storm's ownership group suspended operations.

column1: Tampa was also home to the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League. The Bandits made the playoffs twice in their three seasons under head coach Steve Spurrier and drew league-leading crowds to Tampa Stadium
column2: but the team folded along with the rest of the USFL after the 1985 season. They played at Tampa Stadium
column3: which hosted the 1984 USFL Championship Game.

column1: The Tampa Bay Vipers play in the second edition of the XFL. Their inaugural season was cut short after five weeks due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Raymond James Stadium hosted the 2017 College Football Playoff National Championship.

The Tampa Bay area has long been home to nationally competitive amateur baseball and has hosted spring training and minor league teams for over a century. Tampa became the first city in Florida to host a major league team for spring training in 1913
column2: when the Chicago Cubs trained at Plant Field. The Tampa Smokers were the city's first minor league team
column3: beginning play as charter members of the new Florida State League in 1919.

column1: After decades of trying to lure an existing Major League Baseball franchise
column2: the Tampa Bay area finally gained a team in 1998
column3: when the expansion Tampa Bay Devil Rays began play at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg. After a decade of futility on the field
column4: the Devil Rays shortened their nickname to simply Rays in 2008 and promptly won the 2008 American League Pennant
column5: finishing runner up in World Series. They also won American League East titles in 2008 and 2010 under manager Joe Maddon before slipping back in the standings.

column2: the Rays began the process of searching for a stadium site closer to the center of the area's population
column3: possibly in Tampa. However
column4: over a decade later
column5: rivalry between Tampa and St. Petersburg and the challenges of financing a new ballpark has kept the Rays playing in Tropicana Field.In 2020
column6: the Rays won the AL East for the first time in a decade with the best record in the American League. Due to the COVID-19 shortened season
column7: 16 teams made the playoffs
column8: so the Rays had to play a best of 3 series against the division rival Toronto Blue Jays in the first round where they swept the visitors in two games at Tropicana Field. then play a divisional series against the New York Yankees
column9: which they won in 5 games at a neutral site in San Diego. The Rays then faced the Astros
column10: who had defeated them in the divisional round the previous year. Tampa Bay went out to a quick 3-0 series lead
column11: but Houston came back to tie the series 3-3. The Rays avoided the reverse sweep in Game 7 and won their second American League Pennant.

column1: Several Major League baseball teams conduct spring training in the area
column2: and most also operate minor league teams in the Class-A Florida State League. The major league New York Yankees and the affiliated minor league Tampa Tarpons use George M. Steinbrenner Field across Dale Mabry Highway from Raymond James Stadium.

column1: The NHL's Tampa Bay Lightning was established in 1992
column2: and play their home games at Amalie Arena in downtown Tampa. In 2004
column3: the team won their first Stanley Cup by defeating the Calgary Flames in 7 games. The Lightning lost the Eastern Conference Final in 2011 in 7 games against the eventual champion Boston Bruins. The Bolts were Eastern Conference champions in 2015
column4: losing to the Chicago Blackhawks in the Finals. They returned to the Eastern Conference Final in 2016 but lost in 7 games to the eventual champion Pittsburgh Penguins. They returned again to the Eastern Conference Final in 2018 but lost in 7 games to the eventual champion Washington Capitals. The Lightning won a second Stanley Cup championship in 2020
column5: defeating the Dallas Stars in 6 games. Tampa hosted the skills contests and 2018 NHL All-Star Game weekend on January 27–28

column1: The Tampa Bay Rowdies compete in the United Soccer League (2nd Division) after spending their first 6 seasons in the North American Soccer League. The team began play at Tampa's George M. Steinbrenner Field in 2010
column2: then moved to St. Petersburg's Al Lang Field in 2011. The Rowdies won their first league championship in Soccer Bowl 2012.
Tampa had hosted two top-level soccer teams. The Tampa Bay Rowdies of the original North American Soccer League was the area's first major sports franchise
column3: beginning play in 1975 at Tampa Stadium. The Rowdies were an immediate success
column4: drawing good crowds and winning Soccer Bowl '75 in their first season to bring Tampa its first professional sports championship. Though the NASL ceased operations in 1984
column5: the Rowdies continued to compete in various soccer leagues until finally folding in 1993.

column1: The success of the Rowdies prompted Major League Soccer (MLS) to award Tampa a charter member of the new league in 1996. The Tampa Bay Mutiny were the first MLS Supporters' Shield winner and had much early success beginning in 1996. However
column2: the club folded in 2001 when local ownership could not be secured mainly due to a financially poor lease agreement for Raymond James Stadium. The city has no current representation in MLS
column3: however
column4: the Rowdies are seeking to join the league.

column1: The Tampa Bay Titans play in The Basketball League (TBL).  Their home games are played at Pasco–Hernando State College.
The St. Pete Tide and the Tampa Gunners play in the Florida Basketball Association (FBA).  The Tide's home games are played at St. Petersburg Catholic High School
column2: and the Gunners are a travel team.

column1: The University of South Florida is the only NCAA Division I sports program in Tampa. USF began playing intercollegiate sports in 1965. The Bulls established a men's basketball team in 1971 and a football team in 1997. The Bulls joined the Big East in 2005
column2: and the football team rose to as high as #2 in the BCS rankings in 2007. They are now part of the American Athletic Conference. USF has won one NCAA National Championship.The University of Tampa Spartans compete at the NCAA Division II level in the Sunshine State Conference (SSC). They have won a total of 18 Division II National Championships
column3: including eight in baseball.The Hillsborough Community College Hawks are an NJCAA Division I junior college team and a member of the Florida College System Activities Association they compete in the Suncoast Conference and the Southern Conference in Region VIII of The National Junior College Athletic Association (NJCAA).

column1: Tampa is governed under the strong mayor form of government. The Mayor of Tampa is the chief executive officer of city government and is elected in four-year terms
column2: with a limit of two consecutive terms. The current mayor is Jane Castor
column3: who took office on May 1

column1: The City Council is a legislative body served by seven members. Four members are elected from specific numbered areas designated City Districts
column2: and the other three are "at-large" members (serving citywide).

column1: The city of Tampa is served by Tampa Fire Rescue. With 22 fire stations
column2: the department provides fire and medical protection for Tampa and New Tampa
column3: and provides support to other departments such as Tampa International Airport
column4: Hillsborough County Fire Rescue and MacDill Air Force Base 6th Medical Group.

column1: The city of Tampa has a large police department that provides law enforcement services. The Tampa Police Department has over 1000 sworn officers and many civilian service support personnel.
Public primary and secondary education is operated by Hillsborough County Public Schools
column2: officially known as the School District of Hillsborough County (SDHC). It is the eighth-largest school district in the United States
column3: with around 189
column4: 469 enrolled students. SDHC runs 208 schools
column5: 133 being elementary
column6: 42 middle
column7: 27 high schools
column8: two K-8s
column9: and four career centers. There are 73 additional schools in the district that are charter
column11: alternative
column12: etc. Twelve out of 27 high schools in the SDHC are included in Newsweek's list of America's Best High Schools.

column1: Tampa's library system is operated by the Tampa-Hillsborough County Public Library System. THPLS operates 25 libraries throughout Tampa and Hillsborough County
column2: including the John F. Germany Public Library in Downtown Tampa. The Tampa library system first started in the early 20th century
column3: with the West Tampa Library
column4: which was made possible with funds donated by Andrew Carnegie. Tampa's libraries are also a part of a larger library network
column5: The Hillsborough County Public Library Cooperative
column6: which includes the libraries of the neighboring municipalities of Temple Terrace and Plant City.

column1: There are a number of institutions of higher education in Tampa.
The city is home to the main campus of the University of South Florida (USF)
column2: a member of the State University System of Florida founded in 1956. In 2010
column3: it was the eleventh highest individual campus enrollment in the U.S. with over 46
column4: 000 students. The University of Tampa (UT) is a private
column5: four-year liberal arts institution. It was founded in 1931
column6: and in 1933
column7: it moved into the former Tampa Bay Hotel across the Hillsborough River from downtown Tampa. "UT" has undergone several expansions in recent years
column8: and had an enrollment of over 9000 students in 2018.Hillsborough Community College is a two-year community college in the Florida College System with campuses in Tampa and Hillsborough County. Southern Technical College is a private two-year college that operates a campus in Tampa. Hillsborough Technical Education Centers (HiTEC) is the postsecondary extension of the local areas Public Schools district. The schools provide for a variety of technical training certification courses as well as job placement skills.

column1: The Stetson University College of Law is in Gulfport and has a second campus

column3: in downtown Tampa. The Law Center houses the Tampa branch of Florida's Second District Court of Appeal.Other colleges and universities in the wider Tampa Bay Area include Jersey College
column4: Eckerd College
column5: and St. Petersburg College in St. Petersburg.

column1: Three motor vehicle bridges cross Tampa Bay to Pinellas County from Tampa city limits: the Howard Frankland Bridge (I-275)
column2: the Courtney Campbell Causeway (SR 60)
column3: and the Gandy Bridge (U.S. 92). The old Gandy Bridge was completely replaced by new spans during the 1990s
column4: but a span of the old bridge was saved and converted into a pedestrian and biking bridge renamed The Friendship Trail. It was the longest overwater recreation trail in the world. However
column5: the bridge was closed in 2008 due to structural problems.

column1: Tampa has several freeways which serve the city. There are two tolled freeways bringing traffic in and out of Tampa. The Lee Roy Selmon Expressway (SR 618) (formerly known as the Crosstown Expressway)
column2: runs from suburban Brandon at its eastern terminus
column3: through Downtown Tampa
column4: to the neighborhoods in South Tampa (near MacDill Air Force Base) at its western terminus. The Veterans Expressway (SR 589)
column5: meanwhile connects Tampa International Airport and the bay bridges to the northwestern suburbs of Carrollwood
column6: Northdale
column7: Westchase
column8: Citrus Park
column9: Cheval
column11: before continuing north as the Suncoast Parkway into Pasco and Hernando counties.

column1: Three of the city's freeways carry the interstate highway designation. Interstate 4 and Interstate 275 cut across the city and intersect near downtown. Interstate 75 runs along the east side of town for much of its route through Hillsborough County until veering to the west to bisect New Tampa.

column2: major surface roads serve as main arteries of the city. These roads are Hillsborough Avenue (U.S. 92 and U.S. 41)
column3: Dale Mabry Highway (U.S. 92)

column8: Busch Boulevard

column1: Tampa is served by three airports (one in Tampa
column2: two in the metro area) that provide significant scheduled passenger air service:

column1: Tampa International Airport (IATA: TPA) is Tampa's main airport and the primary location for commercial passenger airline service into the Tampa Bay area. It is also a consistent favorite in surveys of the industry and the traveling public. The readers of Condé Nast Traveler have frequently placed Tampa International in their list of Best Airports
column2: ranking it #1 in 2003
column3: and #2 in 2008 A survey by Zagat in 2007 ranked Tampa International first among U.S. airports in overall quality. During 2008
column4: it was the 26th-busiest airport in North America.

column1: St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport (IATA: PIE) lies just across the bay from Tampa International Airport in neighboring Pinellas County. The airport has become a popular destination for discount carriers
column2: with over 90% of its flights are on low-cost carrier Allegiant Air. A joint civil-military aviation facility
column3: it is also home to Coast Guard Air Station Clearwater
column4: the largest air station in the U.S. Coast Guard.

column1: Sarasota–Bradenton International Airport (IATA: SRQ) is in nearby Sarasota. Sarasota airport has more flights to Delta's Atlanta hub than any other city
column2: but also serves several other large U.S. cities.

column1: Tampa's intercity passenger rail service is based at Tampa Union Station
column2: a historic facility
column3: adjacent to downtown between the Channel District and Ybor City. The station is served by Amtrak's Silver Star
column4: which calls on Tampa twice daily: southbound to Miami and northbound for New York City. Union Station also serves as the transfer hub for Amtrak Thruway Motorcoach service
column5: offering bus connections to several cities in southwest Florida and to Orlando.Uceta Rail Yard on Tampa's east side services CSX as a storage and intermodal freight transport facility. Freight and container cargo operations at the city's seaports also depend upon dockside rail facilities.

column1: The Port of Tampa is the largest port in Florida in throughput tonnage
column2: making it one of the busiest commercial ports in North America. Petroleum and phosphate are the lead commodities
column3: accounting for two-thirds of the 37 million tons of total bulk and general cargo handled by the port in 2009. The port is also home to Foreign Trade Zone #79
column4: which assists companies in Tampa Bay and along the I-4 Corridor in importing
column5: exporting
column6: manufacturing
column7: and distribution activities as part of the United States foreign trade zone program.Weekly containerized cargo service is available in the Port of Tampa. Cargo service is offered by Ports America
column8: Zim American Integrated Shipping Company
column9: and MSC which has recently partnered with Zim. 3
column11: 250 TEU containerships regularly call the Port of Tampa.

column1: The bay bottom is very sandy
column2: with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers constantly dredging the ship channels to keep them navigable to large cargo ships.

column1: Public mass transit in Tampa is operated by the Hillsborough Area Regional Transit Authority (HART)
column2: and includes public bus as well as a streetcar line. The HART bus system's main hub is the Marion Transit Center in Downtown Tampa
column3: serving nearly 30 local and express routes. HART also operates a rapid-transit bus system called MetroRapid that runs between Downtown and the University of South Florida.The TECO Line Streetcar provides electric streetcar service along eleven stations on a 2.7-mile (4.3 km) route
column4: connecting Ybor City
column5: the Channel District
column6: the Tampa Convention Center
column7: and downtown Tampa. The TECO Line fleet features varnished wood interiors reminiscent of late 19th and mid-20th century streetcars.Limited transportation by privately operated "Neighborhood Electric Vehicles" (NEV) is available
column8: primarily in Downtown Tampa and Ybor City. Water taxis are available on a charter basis for tours along the downtown waterfront and the Hillsborough River.

column1: The Tampa Bay Area Regional Transportation Authority (TBARTA) develops bus
column2: light rail
column3: and other transportation options for the seven-county Tampa Bay area.

column1: Tampa and its surrounding suburbs are host to over 20 hospitals
column2: four trauma centers
column3: and multiple Cancer treatment centers. Three of the area's hospitals were ranked among "America's best hospitals" by US News and World Report. Tampa is also home to many health research institutions. The major hospitals in Tampa include Tampa General Hospital
column4: St. Joseph's Children's & Women's Hospital
column5: James A. Haley Veterans Hospital
column6: H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center & Research Institute
column7: and The Pepin Heart Institute. Shriners Hospitals for Children is based in Tampa. USF's Byrd Alzheimer's Institute is both a prominent research facility and Alzheimer's patient care center in Tampa. Along with human health care
column8: there are hundreds of animal medical centers including a Humane Society of America.

column1: Water in the area is managed by the Southwest Florida Water Management District. The water is mainly supplied by the Hillsborough River
column2: which in turn arises from the Green Swamp
column3: but several other rivers and desalination plants in the area contribute to the supply. Power is mainly generated by TECO Energy.
